illers Island Road
traverses Black Marsh, the 1,310 acres
of marshland and farm fields that
the state acquired from Bethlehem
Steel in 1988. This tract is the last
substantial area of open space on
the Patapsco Neck. As such, it is
particularly important as an eco-
logical resource.

- While various committees of
concerned citizens, county, and state
personnel, and environmentalists
debate future uses of the whole tract,
650 acres already have been set aside
as a Natural Heritage Area (NHA).
Largely marshland with a wooded buf-
fer, this NHA is an important habitat
for five endangered floral species and
two endangered fauna species.

The Natural Heritage Area will
remain largely unchanged in the
future. Although regulations are in the
formulation stage, there is no doubt
that this fragile ecosystem will be
preserved. Limited public access for
nature study will be planned. While
endangered species need special pro-
tection, the Natural Heritage Area is
important for all manner of wildlife on
Patapsco Neck. It is their last refuge
of open space juxtaposed with one of
the most heavily industrialized areas
of the state.

Continue along Millers Island
Road to the community of Millers
Island on the tip of Cuckold Point.
Although all of the waterfront is
privately owned, there is a plethora of
water-oriented activities available.
This community is surrounded by
water with the Bay on one side and
Back River on the other. Follow
Millers Island Road to Cuckold Point
Road, Millers Island Boulevard, or
Chesapeake Avenue. Whichever you
chose, you’ll find yourself at the water-
front. Park your car and walk to the
end of the road for an expansive view
of the confluence of bay and river, in-
terrupted only by fishing piers, light-
houses, and boats of every description.

If just looking is not enough,
there is more available. Fishing, for
example. Bring a rod and some
nightcrawlers and try your luck from
one of the fishing piers open to the
public. Or, if crabs are on your agenda,
cruise the streets looking for
homemade signs or sniff the air for
the unmistakable odor of Old Bay
and crabs.

For a more adventurous trip,
rent a boat from one of the numerous
boat rental yards. Row or motor to
Hart-Miller or Pleasure Islands,
located only a few hundred yards off-
shore. The portion of Hart-Miller not
used for harbor dredging is part of the
Gunpowder Falls State Park System.
You can join hundreds of boats
anchored off its beach on a summer

weekend. Picnickers
enjoy the bayside tables.
Overnight camping is
available at five primi-
tive campsites.

Planned improve-

ments include both a
raised boardwalk
through the
marsh to view
the abundant
wildlife and an
observation
tower to

peer over

the dike into
the dredge
contain-
ment

area.

Pleasure Island was an amuse-
ment park until 1964 when the bridge
connecting the island to the peninsula
was destroyed in a severe storm. Now
a part of the state park system, two
tiny beaches offer places to swim
or picnic.

For those who prefer to dine
indoors, several restaurants are
located bayside on Cuckold Point Road
or riverside on Hinton Avenue. Local
restauranteurs pride themselves on of-
fering a wide-ranging selection of fresh
seafood favorites designed to please
every member of the family.

Part of the Black Marsh tract includes
the 30 acres of the old Bay Shore Park, which
operated from 1906 to 1947. Bay Shore Park
was a family-oriented waterfront amusement
park built on a point of land between Shallow
Creek and the Chesapeake Bay. It was con-
structed by United Railways, the local trolley
company, to spur ridership on the trolley line
by providing an attractive destination for
city dwellers. Two fashionable architects were
commissioned to design the colonial-style
pavilions. They created casino-like structures



15

open to the breezes. The buildings were painted
white and trimmed with handsome railings,
flag poles, verandas, and flower displays.

A trolley line was constructed from
Sparrow’s Point to Bay Shore as a loop which
paralleled the shore for over a mile. City
dwellers could board the trolley in Baltimore
at the intersection of Baltimore and Holliday
Streets and ride 12 miles through farm fields,
woodlands, and along county roads. Then, the
Bay came into view, swelling anticipation of
pleasure to come. The trolley, the only one
in the nation to pass under a roller coaster,
concluded its journey at the station in Bay
Shore Park.

Families were greeted by an orna-
mental fountain gaily spraying in the flower-
filled central square. Bands played. The

carousel spun. roller-coaster, called the
Thingumajig, swooped by park goers. Crowds
sauntered along heading for the music pavilion
with its orchestra shell that seated 2,000, the
dancing pavilion above the billiard hall, or the
10-alley bowling building. A picnic lunch could
be spread on one of the 1,000 picnic tables
under the trees to be enjoyed along with
views of the beds of peonies, iris, and
geraniums and cool bay breezes.

The beach was popular, especially
with the children. They played on an elaborate
swing system set in the shallow water that
allowed them to grasp a dangled cable, climb
up, and splash into the water. Ornamental
shelters shaded watchful parents on the
beach’s edge. With a quarter mile of
beachfront and water that sloped gently out
into the Bay, Bay Shore Park was an ideal
swimming location.

Another favorite activity at Bay Shore
was dining at the Bay Shore Park Hotel.
Mrs. Estella Spencer recalled, “it was an
establishment which operated only dining

f you are driving to historic
Dundalk along Dundalk Avenue, you
know immediately when you have
arrived in the historic area. Lines of
brick row houses yield to lively
continental-style architecture. The
First Baptist Church, with its distine-
tive arched windows, anchors this
corner of the historic district.

To best appreciate historic
Dundalk, park in the lot at Market
Place and stroll along the pleasant,
shaded streets, admiring the
manicured parks, bustling commercial
center and tidy residences. Residential
Dundalk began in 1916 under the
ownership of the Bethlehem Steel
Corporation. The houses of hollow tile
covered with stucco as well as the
curvilinear street plan, were designed
in the Olmsted-style by Edward H.
Boulton, president of the Roland Park
Company. Boulton planned a neat,
almost symmetrical community, that
includes the shopping area, the
elementary school, parks, and rows of
streets radiating around a town center.

rooms, and it was well known for its excellent
food . . . I remember the meals principally as
huge affairs consisting of so much foog—-—fried
chicken and crab imperial among other things
that you couldn’t eat it all. I remember the
great expanses of tables in the dining room,
all set with great white cloths, shining crystal,
and beautiful silver.”

Aviation history was made at Bay
Shore Park. In 1925, the park was the site of





































the 12-year-old Schneider Cup Race, an
international ‘“‘spectacle of aviation engineer-
ing, design, construction, and daredevils,”
according to Evening Sun columnist Jacques
Kelly. The 50-kilometer, 7-lap race was won
by James H. Doolittle, later to become a
famous World War 11 fighter pilot.

} This idyllic summer playground was
bulldozed in 1947 to make way for a planned
industrial expansion that never happened.
Only the skeleton of the trolley barn now
survives, in mute testimony of the thousands
of laughing families who passed under its iron
arms in happier days.

0

Beginning at the southern end
of the historic district along Shipping
Place is St. George’s and St. Mat-
thew’s Episcopal Church. Built in
1928, its architecture is a blend of
Tudor Revival and Gothic Revival
styles, featuring a half-timbered porch
and pointed-arch windows. Across
from the church is the Dunkirk
Building. This building, along with the
adjacent Dunleer and Dundalk
buildings, are the major commerecial
buildings which comprise the shopping
center of Dundalk. The Dunleer and
Dunkirk buildings were constructed in
1929. Designed in the Colonial Revival
Style, they are nearly identical in
appearance. The Dundalk Building is
the oldest commercial building in Dun-
dalk. Designed by architect Edward L.
Palmer in 1919, it is one of the state’s
earliest shopping-center buildings.
Palmer worked extensively in Roland
Park, and his design for this building
was probably inspired by the Roland
Park Shopping Center, considered
one of the oldest shopping centers in
the nation.

The Dundalk Police Station is
across Market Place from the Dundalk
Building. The station was designed by
architect William Emory and was built
in 1920. The building originally hous-
ed both the police and fire depart-
ments. The tower at the rear of the
building was originally used to hang
fire hoses.

Continuing up Shipping Place
is the Strand Theatre, which was
designed by architect John F. Eyring







Heritage Park, Dundalk

in 1926. The large marquee and first-
floor facade were added in the 1940s,
but the second floor retains much of its
original appearance.

Across from the Strand on
North Center Place is the Reier
House. Built for local physician Dr.
Adam Reier in 1927, the building later
housed offices of the Dundalk
Community College and the Baltimore
County government. The building now
serves as offices for the local news-
paper, The Dundalk Eagle.

The Reier House faces Veteran’s
Park. This park was part of Dundalk’s
original plan and functions as a ‘““village
green.”’” The prominent monument to
Dundalk service veterans gives the
park its name. Located in the park is
the Dundalk Library. The building was
constructed in 1929 and originally
served as offices for the Dundalk
Company. Symbolizing that company,
a letter “D” decorates the area just
above the main entrance. The Dundalk
Library is another good example of the
Colonial Revival style.

As you stroll through the residen-
tial streets, notice the architecture.
Characteristics shared by all of the
houses include stucco exteriors and pic-
turesque combinations of roof shapes.
In addition to the single and multii%rn—
ily houses, two boarding houses were
constructed. Numbers One and Two
Friendship Circle were originally
designed to house unmarried shipyard
workers. In later years, the buildings
continued to serve as boarding houses







or hotels and were known as the
Marine Hotel and Dundalk Hotel.

On the other side of the commer-
cial square is another park, Dundalk
Heritage Park. Like Veteran’s Park,
this park was an original feature of the
Dundalk plan. The inclusion of open
space in the community is typical of
“Garden City”’ planning.

The “Garden City”’ of Dundalk
1s a fine example of a well-planned
community maturing gracefully.
Recent revitalization efforts by the
county have replaced street trees,
added walkways and planters, and
erected attractive street lamps.
Seventy-five years after its conception
as a ‘“working man’s Roland Park,”
Dundalk continues to be a pleasant
community. Few urban areas in the
county have the cozy, small town
ambiance of historic Dundalk. It is
both a priceless heritage from the past
and a lesson for the f%lture.

riving along North Point
Road, as it meanders through marsh
and farmland and along the water’s
edge, you follow a long-established
transportation route from Delaware to
Baltimore. From Delaware, products
were shipped by road to Chestertown,
then loaded onto a ferry to cross the
Bay to North Point. Here they were
unloaded and continued along North
Point Road to Baltimore’s ports.

This Patapsco Neck area was
settled very early. Todd’s Inheritance
was one of the first large plantations.
In 1664, Thomas Todd purchased 1,700

acres of land that extended all the way
to where Fort Howard now stands on
the tip of Patapsco Neck. Stop along
the road to appreciate this historic
home overlooking the headwaters of
Shallow Creek. The existing house
was built on the foundation of the
colonial home that the British burned
in 1814. Every year at the Defender’s
Day celebration in September the
property is open to the public.

North Point Road ends at Fort
Howard Park and Veterans Hospital.
For military history buffs, Fort
Howard Park is a wonderful place.
Artillery batteries, magazines and
storehouses fill the site. It is easy to
imagine World War 1 doughboys scan-
ning the horizons for German
battleships steaming up the Bay.

Fort Howard was established in
1899, after the Spanish American War.
Its nearly 150 acres were purchased
by the federal government and
declared a military reservation on
April 18, 1900, by Elihu Root,
Secretary of War. The fort was
named for colonel John Eager
Howard, a noted Baltimore philan-
thropist, former governor of Maryand
and distinguished soldier of the
Maryand Continental Line during the
Revolutionary War. Six batteries were
constructed, each named for local
heroes. Fort Howard, called the
“Bulldog at Baltimore’s Gate,” was
manned by 416 men from the Coast
Artillery Corps, who stood ready to
defend Baltimore from an
attack up the Chesapeake Bay. The
fort was heavily armed and equipped
with the most modern weaponry,
including 12-inch guns that fired
1,046-pound projectiles. |

The fort’s capacity was
strengthened during World War I.
Troops were doubled and put on a
wartime status. For gunnery prac-
tice, the soldiers conducted mock drills
by firing at passing cargo and
passenger steamers.

In addition to the well-manned
batteries, torpedoes and mines were
stored here in a special building.
The harbor entrance was sealed off by
electric mines connected by a
heavy underwater cable. A three-
foot-wide rail facility ran to the wharf
to dispense the mines into the ship-
ping channel at the site of the pres-
ent fishing pier on the Veterans
Hospital property.

During this era, Fort Howard
became a thriving community. The
base boasted residences for officers,
bachelors and enlisted men. There was
a post exchange, hospital, clothing
department, and food storage com-
missary. For recreation there were
tennis courts, a football field, golf
course, and a “moving picture parlor.”

Fort Howard Park has more to
offer than just military history. It is
a terrific place for a family picnic. The
military ruins make a wonderful place
for children to climb, play hide-and-
seek and all the other energetic things
they like to do. Picnic tables are set
under the trees next to the Bay from
which you can see cargo ships in the
channel and sailboats gliding by closer
to shore. Catfish and white perch
abound where the fishing pier extends
into the Bay.

As you return homeward on
North Point Road, turn onto Avenue C,
and stop for a look across the marsh
grass and Old Road Bay to the
Bethlehem Steel plant on Sparrows
Point. This view neatly
sums up the
essence of this area
of Baltimore County.
Nature at its best—
sun sparkling on the
waters of the Bay,
ducks taking flight
from their shallow
water sanctuary,
and marsh
grasses bending
in the breeze
—contrasting
with the
omnipresent
industry

Building. This building, along with the
adjacent Dunleer and Dundalk
buildings, are the major commerecial
buildings which comprise the shopping
center of Dundalk. The Dunleer and
Dunkirk buildings were constructed in
1929. Designed in the Colonial Revival
Style, they are nearly identical in
appearance. The Dundalk Building is
the oldest commercial building in Dun-
dalk. Designed by architect Edward L.
Palmer in 1919, it is one of the state’s
earliest shopping-center buildings.
Palmer worked extensively in Roland
Park, and his design for this building
was probably inspired by the Roland
Park Shopping Center, considered
one of the oldest shopping centers in
the nation.

The Dundalk Police Station is
across Market Place from the Dundalk
Building. The station was designed by
architect William Emory and was built
in 1920. The building originally hous-
ed both the police and fire depart-
ments. The tower at the rear of the
building was originally used to hang
fire hoses.

Continuing up Shipping Place
is the Strand Theatre, which was
designed by architect John F. Eyring







Heritage Park, Dundalk

in 1926. The large marquee and first-
floor facade were added in the 1940s,
but the second floor retains much of its
original appearance.

Across from the Strand on
North Center Place is the Reier
House. Built for local physician Dr.
Adam Reier in 1927, the building later
housed offices of the Dundalk
Community College and the Baltimore
County government. The building now
serves as offices for the local news-
paper, The Dundalk Eagle.

The Reier House faces Veteran’s
Park. This park was part of Dundalk’s
original plan and functions as a ‘““village
green.”’” The prominent monument to
Dundalk service veterans gives the
park its name. Located in the park is
the Dundalk Library. The building was
constructed in 1929 and originally
served as offices for the Dundalk
Company. Symbolizing that company,
a letter “D” decorates the area just
above the main entrance. The Dundalk
Library is another good example of the
Colonial Revival style.

As you stroll through the residen-
tial streets, notice the architecture.
Characteristics shared by all of the
houses include stucco exteriors and pic-
turesque combinations of roof shapes.
In addition to the single and multii%rn—
ily houses, two boarding houses were
constructed. Numbers One and Two
Friendship Circle were originally
designed to house unmarried shipyard
workers. In later years, the buildings
continued to serve as boarding houses







or hotels and were known as the
Marine Hotel and Dundalk Hotel.

On the other side of the commer-
cial square is another park, Dundalk
Heritage Park. Like Veteran’s Park,
this park was an original feature of the
Dundalk plan. The inclusion of open
space in the community is typical of
“Garden City”’ planning.

The “Garden City”’ of Dundalk
1s a fine example of a well-planned
community maturing gracefully.
Recent revitalization efforts by the
county have replaced street trees,
added walkways and planters, and
erected attractive street lamps.
Seventy-five years after its conception
as a ‘“working man’s Roland Park,”
Dundalk continues to be a pleasant
community. Few urban areas in the
county have the cozy, small town
ambiance of historic Dundalk. It is
both a priceless heritage from the past
and a lesson for the f%lture.

North Point Road ends at Fort

For military history buffs, Fort

Fort Howard was established in
1899, after the Spanish American War.
Its nearly 150 acres were purchased
by the federal government and
declared a military reservation on
April 18, 1900, by Elihu Root,
Secretary of War. The fort was
named for colonel John Eager
Howard, a noted Baltimore philan-
thropist, former governor of Maryand
and distinguished soldier of the
Maryand Continental Line during the
Revolutionary War. Six batteries were
constructed, each named for local
heroes. Fort Howard, called the
“Bulldog at Baltimore’s Gate,” was
manned by 416 men from the Coast
Artillery Corps, who stood ready to
defend Baltimore from an
attack up the Chesapeake Bay. The
fort was heavily armed and equipped
with the most modern weaponry,
including 12-inch guns that fired
1,046-pound projectiles. |

The fort’s capacity was
strengthened during World War I.
Troops were doubled and put on a
wartime status. For gunnery prac-
tice, the soldiers conducted mock drills
by firing at passing cargo and
passenger steamers.

In addition to the well-manned
batteries, torpedoes and mines were
stored here in a special building.
The harbor entrance was sealed off by
electric mines connected by a
heavy underwater cable. A three-
foot-wide rail facility ran to the wharf
to dispense the mines into the ship-
ping channel at the site of the pres-
ent fishing pier on the Veterans
Hospital property.

During this era, Fort Howard
became a thriving community. The
base boasted residences for officers,
bachelors and enlisted men. There was
a post exchange, hospital, clothing
department, and food storage com-
missary. For recreation there were
tennis courts, a football field, golf
course, and a “moving picture parlor.”

Fort Howard Park has more to
offer than just military history. It is
a terrific place for a family picnic. The
military ruins make a wonderful place
for children to climb, play hide-and-
seek and all the other energetic things
they like to do. Picnic tables are set
under the trees next to the Bay from
which you can see cargo ships in the
channel and sailboats gliding by closer
to shore. Catfish and white perch
abound where the fishing pier extends
into the Bay.

As you return homeward on
North Point Road, turn onto Avenue C,
and stop for a look across the marsh
grass and Old Road Bay to the
Bethlehem Steel plant on Sparrows
Point. This view neatly
sums up the
essence of this area
of Baltimore County.
Nature at its best—
sun sparkling on the
waters of the Bay,
ducks taking flight
from their shallow
water sanctuary,
and marsh
grasses bending
in the breeze
—contrasting
with the
